comments.commentBody: He's not naturalizing anyone, he's choosing, as is his right, how the laws will be enforced.  Stop waving the Constitution around when you have no idea what you're talking about.

Issuing an executive order that exercises the prosecutorial discretion the Constitution gives the executive branch - that is not the same as making a law. Prosecutorial discretion is discretion in who is prosecuted under a law. Big difference from making a law.

Congress could have made a law at any time, and they still can, and they should, but they have given no indication they ever will.
Some of us opposed the Reagan and Bush amnesties, and oppose the Obama amnesty as well.  Overreach is overreach no matter which president or party does it.

" this under executive authority, because he has given up waiting for Congress to act."

Quite a calculated sentence.

When the executive gives up on the legislature, he does what needs to be done. Any fasces around as symbols if authority?

Elitist. Anti democratic. Corrupt.

'Germany's fiscal responsibility may irk the author, but it is the main reason why they can dictate the financial practices employed in several other countries.'

Uuuh don't tell!
-(or everybody wants to be 'flush'?)

"...but there are situations where fiscal responsibility can restore confidence from foreign investors."
Any evidence that 1-Japan is in one of those situations and 2-"restoring confidence from foreign investors" is Japan's priority over inflation?

As for German's responsability, the same author wrote this: http://krugman.blogs.nytimes.com/2012/05/06/german-adjustment/

I understand why Dr. Krugman recommends even more fiscal stimulus in this situation because Japan has its own currency, but there are situations where fiscal responsibility can restore confidence from foreign investors. Adding trillions in stimulus around the world may push stock prices to new all time highs every day, but it does very little to boost GDP growth or job numbers outside the United States. With Japan's declining population and using debt to pay for nearly half their country's budget every year, it has already led them down a path which they will never be able to reverse unless they stop offering public services for a while. Germany's fiscal responsibility may irk the author, but it is the main reason why they can dictate the financial practices employed in several other countries. Kicking the can down the road in terms of budget deficits has made life painfully easy for baby boomers, but it is forcing people my age to pick up the tab.

As I have written previously in NYT comments, Uber's business model disgusts me. The company's success is based in part on paying its drivers poorly for the privilege of supplying capital equipment (cars) and labor to a firm with an $18 billion market cap. Uber is the WalMart of transport.

Second, Uber's business model is based on the evasion of taxi regulations: it contends that it is a "ride sharing" company, not a taxi service. In fact, Uber is providing taxi service: transporting patrons from one location to another for profit. There are two potential solutions to this problem: subject Uber and other "ride sharing" suppliers to taxi regulation (my preferred outcome), or stop regulating taxis. A two-tiered system, in which some providers are regulated and others are not, is unfair.

Uber's abuse of customer data gives me one more reason to be critical of this firm. My message to Uber's management, in the words of the late Joan Rivers: "Oh, grow up!"
Wait.... are you saying there was a poll and the Indian Tribes approved housing the illegal aliens on their reservations?
If you lived in a big immigrant neighborhood in Portland, you might understand peoples frustration with immigration. It ruins the neighborhoods

Oh goody!  Let's go back to the good old days:  Only white land owners could be citizens.  Or how about only people who have served in the armed forces?  Both systems have been used in the past, unfortunately the countries who had such a system of class distinction no longer exist, they were overthrown by the underclass.  What was that saying?  Something about those who don't study history are doomed to repeat it?
Larry, I think that the writer is making the same point that you are. The "adults not being in charge" comment is intended ironically.
They're breaking the law. Why should they get to move around with impugnity?

The point is that 5 million people will be able to go shopping without worry of being deported, or go to work without being seized in a raid, or worry about their US citizen children who they may have had to leave behind to have a better life.

From the time of Abraham, welcoming the "alien" has been a clear commandment hence the broad religious support for this first step. These folks have lived here for at least 5 years, peacefully, and even paying their taxes. They have had children imbued with the American work ethic and dream who are some of the top graduates at our schools. What's to be afraid of? I'd say, "Welcome; come join us in the light!"
So do the millions of uninsured citizens thanks to the GOP's refusal to work with President Obama to fix our health care system.

What is good for americans workers and their families is good paying union jobs something most republicans are against. Practically all of their policies are designed to lower wages and side with big business, Romney comes to mind.
It's amazing how so many americans vote against their own economic interest, quite baffling to be honest.

I believe that the requirement for hospitals to treat with or without payment was put into effect a couple of decades ago. Nothing says it could not be repealed.

On the other hand, if they disobey the law by being in the US, what makes you think that they will follow a mandate to get health insurance?
Martin, think this is a case of ask.

Yup, to lise , the illegals in your school , pay a fee to get in just like any other public high school and any other parent , while their parents pay taxes thru their tax id numbers without any benefits , no retirement or even tax returns , so you miss conservative are getting paid by people who get nothing in return so essentially free money so id say you have it made
I agree. I posted an excerpt from her comment on a friend's facebook after my friend suggested that Obama's actions were likely to bring us a Democrat victory in 2016.

AMEN, AMEN, AMEN. I agree with everything she wrote. I too have been a lifelong Democrat, but have taken a step back.  I hope to find a new party that advocates and fights for Americans in need, not illegal immigrants.

The following is a comment from Lise, posted below, but so utterly indicative of the exasperation of many in this country that it should be repeated. I have no idea who Lise is, but I agree wholeheartedly with her comment.

"I am tired. Tired of playing by the rules, then hearing that those who didn't now come before me in line, simply because their narratives are more piteous. Tired of working hard then feeling duped, believing in the case for insurance under the ACA - because sharing the risk and cost would benefit "all" and eventually lower costs - then hearing that illegal aliens are exempted and can exploit the system to access healthcare they can't (and have no intention) of paying for. So much for lower costs. Tired of seeing my district's public school resources increasingly gobbled up by what amounts to luxury aisle small-class-size ESL tutoring for students whose parents are very far from insisting - as previous immigrant generations did - that English should become the lingua franca at home. Tired of 25, then 30, then 35 kids in the high school math and history classrooms, 10%, then 20%, then 30% not here legally. I want my government to act for the benefit of its citizens, not to the advantage of non-citizens. I have compassion fatigue. I have voted for the Democrats my entire life. I am finally ready to change my mind about that."

I'm tired of all this drivel that we need immigrants because all Americans benefit from immigrants cheap labor. We don't necessarily need immigrants to keep production and service costs reasonably level.

There are people on welfare in this country who could work the jobs that immigrants do (and that could free government funds for education and upgrading our infrastructure, for example).

But first and foremost, the U.S. can and should have a guest worker program - they come, they work for an X number of years, and they go back to their country (they can also go back and forth while they work here).

It does not benefit our country economically to encourage millions of uneducated and poor people to settle here for the rest of their lives, and gradually bring over more of their uneducated cousins and friends. They end up costing us more in subsidized housing, healthcare, food assistance, education, and criminal justice costs than they contribute via cheap labor.

The problem are not the immigrants but the corporate super rich 1% who has kept the middle class income flat for the last three decades, not paying fair taxes to our country while using our infrastructure. The corporate right wing propaganda is confusing the issue, blaming immigrants for some of the economic issues, while laughing all the way to the bank.

If no serious criminal record exists, allow all these people who want to be American citizens to be American citizens. Let them contribute to our society as previous immigrant populations all have done. Immigrants are not mooches, they work hard, provide for their families and strive to have a better life compared to where they've originated from.

The problem isn't illegal immigrants, it's our broken immigration system. If it takes an educated American like Governor LePage from Maine 11 years for his legally adopted son to become a citizen, then how could any immigrant navigate such a nightmare bureaucratic labyrinth?

I'll take amnesty for 11 million undocumented immigrants to become citizens vs any CEO on Wall Street, as to which is more valuable and which is more detrimental to the economic health of our society.

No one is hateful about LEGAL immigration.
We just dislike the concept that folks can break the rules and get rewarded.
Are you talking about the Pilgrims?

And would Washington State want this pipeline to run through Washington?  Apparently British Columbia didn't, and that was the shortest route available.  So, now you think a 3,000 mile pipeline across the breadbasket is a safe, dependable way to get dirty shale oil to the Gulf for shipment to China?  What do we get, besides the risk of pipeline leaks and spills?  Canadian industrialists get richer, boreal forests get destroyed even more, and China gets more dirty fuel to go with her coal.  Sounds like a winning policy to me.  FYI, I have spent time on Bainbridge Is., and I don't think you want this toxic fuel anywhere near you.  And, Obama has the power of the veto.  He can use until he leaves office.  The State Dept. hasn't finished reviewing the pipeline safety issues.  What's the rush?  The oil spill from the Exxon Valdez is still showing up on the shoreline in Alaska.  Still bubbling up.  The Gulf has been destroyed for decades.  How would you like some bitumen pollution in Pugent Sound?  Thought not.

"Most Unions"?  And, how many jobs?  That is not clear, and temporary at best.  Two years during construction, then maybe 50 jobs to maintain it.  We have a long running recession, and it has affected unions and others.  Dirty shale oil running through a 3,000 mile pipeline, with all the potential for hairline cracks and leaks, does not seem to be a smart choice for job creation.  How about jobs repairing our crumbling infrastructure?  How about jobs repairing our interstate highway system?  How about jobs weatherizing homes against freezing cold and choking heat?  How about jobs upgrading our old schools in the Northeast?  There are a lot of ways to improve our national infrastructure, and that would be money well spent.  Dirty shale oil transport?  Not so much.

We do not have the refinery capacity to refine this dirty fuel; and we are not going to build refineries, very expensive, to refine shale oil so that Canadian industrialists can get richer, and China can get another source of fuel to go with her coal plants.  Why don't we just bang our heads against the nearest wall until we have scrambled our brains completely, and then vote for this pipeline.

Look at the pictures of what Canada has already done to her environment to get at this shale oil.  Canada elected a right wing, anti-environment leader.  We didn't, and if he does the right thing, he will save us from Canada's industrial stupidity.

As I recall the Republicans pushed through this 60 vote majority of the majority through Congress.  Now they are hoist on their own petard.  Even if they manage to vote the pipeline in 2015, Obama can veto, they can override the veto, and the beat goes on.  Meanwhile, Canada's dirty shale oil stays where it is.

The difference, sadly, is that a rail car spill can be cleaned up.  It doesn't impact 3,000 miles of the continental U.S.  The pipeline travels 3,000 miles, subject to hairline cracks and leaks.  The Alaskan pipeline had hairline cracks and leaks, still does.  This is doing the same stupid thing over and over, expecting different results.

No. Even more anti-environment Republicans are going to Congress.  Hope Obama keeps that veto pen handy.  Drag this thing on for a long time, as Congress again votes for the pipeline.  We barely elected these Yahoos and they are preening as if they got a mandate.  Maybe, go through the courts and get an injunction until all issues are reviewed and completed.  The EPA has been suspect for a long time, after her hidden MMA got caught in mining shenanigans.
It would be the next number one target for any terrorist. Why? There's no way to guard it 24/7 and it would devastate our largest aquifer permanently.
